results.title: Farm tractor safety
results.brief_description:
Produced by the U.S Department of Agriculture. Follows a community as they confront the high amount of tractor-related injuries that are occuring and discover ways to counter them.

Largely set at a town meeting where addresses are given by various experts on the dangers of tractors and how to operate them safely. This culminates in an address by a man who lost both his hands in an accident.

Film contains numerous shots of tractors toppling over in varying situations.

results.title: Project the right image
results.brief_description:
English production, NOT made by the Department of Agriculture.

Details hot to and how not to project a 16mm film using a social church gathering as the backdrop. Stars a bumbling projectionist and a priest who first do everything the wrong way and then do everything the correct way.

Comical (in a daggy way) throughout with good use of slapstick humour. Also contains an amusing, very dry voiceover.

results.title: Dirty Harry
results.brief_description:
‘Harry She’llberight’ is a lazy farmer, stuck in the ‘old ways’ of chemical spraying. He provides a ‘worst case scenario’ of chemical spray use. A representative of the Vistorian Department of Agriculture assists Harry in modern spraying techniques, equipment and safety. Along the way we are introduced to different spray epuipment and how it operates away from Harry’s farm.

Harry is a comical character and he eventually gets his act together as the film progresses.

Opening contains nice shots of people picking lettuce and scens inside of a vegetable market.

Good cartoon-like illustrations about chemical spraying safety.

results.title: Young Hands
results.creator_credit: John Martin-Jones, John Appleton and W.H. Shepard
results.brief_description:
Essentially an adverisement for the Juniour Farmer’s Organisation, focusing on how members and the community benefit from it. Stars ‘Hal’, a young man who must continue to run his family’s farm while his father is ill.

Follows Hal and other junior farmers members as they complete various ‘projects’ such as raising lambs, preserving fruit and growing crops. Strong social element within the organisation is exemplified by a social dance that is used to bookend Hal’s story.

Very earnest piece. Amusing end scene.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Martin-Jones, John Appleton and W.H. Shepard

results.title: Archival prints
results.brief_description:
1. The Herringbone Milking Shed - Details the ‘new’ Herringbone Milking Shed, which can improve dramatically the speed in which cows can be milked. Good shots of previous cow-milking techniques, featuring nice colour and framing. Amusing stop-frame animation of how the shed works using toy cows.

With Herringbone Shed, 54 cows can be milked in 45 minutes, pre-mechanised milking could only manage 8 cows per hour. 6 minutes.

  1. Living Like Pigs - Begins with a comical example of how not to keep pigs and then gives numerous examples of how to keep pigs correctly. This includes footage of early piggery automation techniques, as well as more traditional pig care solutions. Contains many shots of pigs drinking milk in different types of pig pens. Nice colour and framing throughout. Good ‘The End’.

  2. Exit T.B - Largely about the importance of Tuberculosis eradication in Victoria. Shows the test undertaken to determine whether a cow has T.B and then what occures to the cow if it does (it is killed). Gives examples of different parts of a cow once infected by T.B. Then goes to show various milk products that are exported overseas and the importance of eradicating T.B so that more products can be exported. Good titles/’The End’.

  3. Poultry Industry Review - Begins with chicks being hatched and sorted into ‘males’ and ‘females’. Shows how battery hens are kept and then focsuses on an egg packing plant and the technology behind it. Good footage of lots of different machinery mainly concerned with extracting the raw egg from the shell. Shows how ‘eating’ chickens are prepared for sale and dressed, then focuses on turkeys and ducks. Fantastic shots of hundreds of Turkeys in a pen and an odd turkey de-feathering machine. Well-edited montage at end featuring chickens, eggs, ducks and turkeys. Good ‘The End’.

results.title: Police horses: who cares?
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture, Reg Boulter and Vivian McWaters
results.brief_description:
Film opens with countryside shots at dawn and then goes into a fast-paced montage sequence of Police Horses in action with a funk soundtrack. Features footage of the horses in country, urban and city settings.

The work of a Victorian Department of Agriculture vet is then spotlighted as he tends to injured horses in the field and in a surgery/lab. Includes footage of a horse being X-Rayed who has an injured hoof.

Switches to the Victorian Police band in action and a their drum-carrying horse. Shots of kids enjoying the band play in an outdoor parade.

Then goes to show a Police Horse trainer at work at the Attwood Department of Agriculture stables. In the background of this training sequence planes from the nearby airport take-off and land in the background.

Similar training seqeunce takes place at the St Kilda Rd barracks with four horses being ridden. Up-beat synthesiser soundtrack. City-scape in the background, featuring the National Gallery of Victoria. This is followed by a more formal performance with full dress uniforms and big-band music. Horses and riders then escort the Queen as she travels in a car on parade down two city streets.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture, Reg Boulter and Vivian McWaters

results.title: 30 Seconds to go
results.brief_description:
Shot at a Mildura television station. Details how an episode of ‘On the Land’ is broadcast by inter-cutting between an installment of the programme and conventional ‘behind the scenes’ footage of a television studio. This includes shots of a camera operator, the television station’s studio, vision-switching and so on.

Actual ‘On the Land’ programme featured, contains information on good seeds to sow and non-hormonal spraying techniques. Contains exterior shots of an orchid.

Film opens with exterior shots of Mildura that begin at river and then move into more general street scenes. This lasts for two minutes.

results.title: Release prints
results.brief_description:
1. Wall to Wall Wool - Documents the process of wool carpet production from design illustrations of a bunch of flowers to the manufacture of finished carpet with similar design. Primarily focuses on the many types of machinery used to create the carpet. Contains nice images of a carpet-making factory, specifically the colourful flower-patterned carpet juxtaposed within an industrial backdrop. Good ‘The End’. (12m 44sec)

  2. Melbourne: Festival City - Made by the Victorian Tourist Development Authority in the 1960s. Essentially an ad for Melbourne, focusing on the ‘highly popular’ Moomba Festival. Great images of large crowds watching the Moomba parade as well as having fun on rides, watching watersports and eating/drinking (including Latte drinkers). Also shows the ‘recently completed’ Sydney Myer Music Bowl, footage of a game of football at the MCG and highlights Melbourne as the ‘Fashion Capital’. Nice closing shot of the city, focusing on St. Pauls and a Fed Square-less Flinders St, as well as the Yarra. Good titles and ‘The End’. (10 mins)

  3. Hydatids - Australian Wool Bureau production. Highlights the dangers of Hydatid disease and the ease of which it can be both contracted and negated. This includes washing hands after having contact with dogs and boiling all sheep offal before feeding it to dogs. Contains footage of a farmer gutting a sheep and cute diagrams of how the hydatids disease can spread from sheep to dogs to humans. (10 mins)

results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: 16mm Prints
results.brief_description:
1. Granville Cattle Shoot - Unedited footage of bulldozers and men clearing land in order to create pens to house cattle. Cattle is then shot in the head and picked-up by a bulldozer/tractor that dumps the dead, or close to dead body in a pit with other bloodied carcases. The pit of dead cows is then filled with soil.

  2. Mice Milking - Documents the process in which scientists at Dandenong milk mice with special machinery. The milk is then given to the American Cancer Council who use it to research cancer treatment. A mouse attached to the milking machine looks quite bizarre. One mouse yeilds a third of a teaspoon of milk per milking session. Good footage of the machine in action.

  3. The problem of Lamb Survival - Shows how the Department of Agriculture is trying to improve the amount of lambs that are born each year and survive to adulthood. Includes footage of a mobile laboratory in the field.

  4. N.A.S.A moon shots - Filmed photographs of general space imagery, focusing on the moon and spacecraft. Contains photograph or earth from space.

  5. Eclipse 23/10/76’ - Rushes of countryside, sheep and cars in the day and at night.
results.description:
1. Granville Cattle Shoot - Unedited footage of bulldozers and men clearing land in order to create pens to house cattle. Cattle is then shot in the head and picked-up by a bulldozer/tractor that dumps the dead, or close to dead body in a pit with other bloodied carcases. The pit of dead cows is then filled with soil.

  2. Mice Milking - Documents the process in which scientists at Dandenong milk mice with special machinery. The milk is then given to the American Cancer Council who use it to research cancer treatment. A mouse attached to the milking machine looks quite bizarre. One mouse yeilds a third of a teaspoon of milk per milking session. Good footage of the machine in action.

  3. The problem of Lamb Survival - Shows how the Department of Agriculture is trying to improve the amount of lambs that are born each year and survive to adulthood. Includes footage of a mobile laboratory in the field.

  4. N.A.S.A moon shots - Filmed photographs of general space imagery, focusing on the moon and spacecraft. Contains photograph or earth from space.

  5. Eclipse 23/10/76’ - Rushes of countryside, sheep and cars in the day and at night.
description_for_label:
1. Granville Cattle Shoot - Unedited footage of bulldozers and men clearing land in order to create pens to house cattle. Cattle is then shot in the head and picked-up by a bulldozer/tractor that dumps the dead, or close to dead body in a pit with other bloodied carcases. The pit of dead cows is then filled with soil.

  2. Mice Milking - Documents the process in which scientists at Dandenong milk mice with special machinery. The milk is then given to the American Cancer Council who use it to research cancer treatment. A mouse attached to the milking machine looks quite bizarre. One mouse yeilds a third of a teaspoon of milk per milking session. Good footage of the machine in action.

  3. The problem of Lamb Survival - Shows how the Department of Agriculture is trying to improve the amount of lambs that are born each year and survive to adulthood. Includes footage of a mobile laboratory in the field.

  4. N.A.S.A moon shots - Filmed photographs of general space imagery, focusing on the moon and spacecraft. Contains photograph or earth from space.

  5. Eclipse 23/10/76’ - Rushes of countryside, sheep and cars in the day and at night.

results.title: Fat pigs are out
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture, Jack Keane and Tony Doogood
results.brief_description:
Film follows a farmer as he foolishes fatens his pigs, only to discover on market day that ‘Fat pigs are out!’. He is then taken to an abattoir and shown the difference between fatty pork and the lean pork that the ‘modern housewife’ now demands.

Comical light-hearted tone throughout. Poor acting and dialogue. Good illustrated titles and ‘The End’.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture, Jack Keane and Tony Doogood
